ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TEACHING OF ABACUS IN SCHOOLS
(Progress)


    1. Mr Koo Tsai Kee asked the Minister for Education if he will report on the progress of the teaching of the abacus in schools.

     The Minister for Education (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1994, the Ministry of Education (MOE) conducted a pilot study on abacus instruction for Primary 3 pupils in seven schools. These schools were representative of the various school types (SAP, Government-aided and Government schools) with a range of mathematics achievements. The objectives of the study were, firstly, to measure the effectiveness of abacus training on mental calculation and understanding of

Column: 1108

place value concepts and, secondly, to assess some affective outcomes related to mathematics such as pupil interest, confidence and perception of ability.

    Results of the pilot study showed that pupils who went through abacus instruction showed improvement in their mental calculations. There were clear indications that pupils in the experimental schools had a more positive attitude towards mathematics. They maintained their interest and exhibited greater confidence in the subject.

    The findings of the pilot study are positive as interest and confidence are important attributes for educational achievement. MOE has thus decided to implement abacus instruction at Primary 3 starting with 15 schools this year. The instructional time for abacus teaching will be 11 hours, or 5% of the total Primary 3 mathematics curriculum time of 220 hours. The programme starts in Term II and continues to Term III.

    MOE will accelerate the implementation next year and in 2-3 years, all schools will conduct abacus lessons for their Primary 3 pupils.

    MOE is also currently conducting another pilot study at Primary 2 level to ascertain the feasibility of implementing abacus instruction at an earlier level.

REMOVAL OF STUDENTS FROM SCHOOL
(Guidelines)


    2. Mr Cheo Chai Chen asked the Minister for Education (a) when a school principal wishes to remove a student from his school, whether he has to seek the approval of his Ministry and give prior written notice to the parents concerned; and (b) under what circumstances a school principal may remove a student from his school and whether his Ministry has a set of guidelines pertaining to this.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, a school principal does not need to seek the approval of the Ministry of Education before removing a student from the school. However, he has to inform the Ministry of his action. He is not required

Column: 1109

to give prior written notice to the parents concerned. Nevertheless, in all cases involving recalcitrant and severe indiscipline necessitating removal from the school, the principal and teachers would have informed the parents and sought to work with them to help the student change his ways before the school is forced to take the ultimate step of expulsion.

    A student is expelled from school only if he commits a very serious offence such as assault and if allowing him to remain in school would threaten the safety of staff and other pupils and severely undermine the good order in the school. Each case is unique with its own contributing and mitigating factors. The principal and his staff are in the best position to judge when a student should be removed from the school for severe indiscipline. If they are in doubt they will consult the Ministry.

CONFESSIONS MADE BY ACCUSED PERSONS TO POLICE
(Rejections by courts)


    3. Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will inform the House on how many occasions in 1993, 1994 and 1995 (up to the latest convenient date) courts in Singapore have rejected confessions made by accused persons to the police.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, from 1993 to April 1995, 166 criminal cases investigated by the police were tried in the High Court. From available police records, confession evidence was ruled inadmissible in four cases. In three of these cases, the accused persons were acquitted. In the fourth case, the accused person was convicted on the basis of other evidence. As for Subordinate Court cases, 39,804 and 41,203 criminal cases were disposed of by the Subordinate Courts in 1993 and 1994 respectively. The number of cases where statements from accused were ruled inadmissible is not readily available.

Column: 1110



    Sir, the trend in the cases tried in the High Court illustrates that the number of confessions ruled inadmissible by the courts is small. Nevertheless, the fact that the courts do reject confession evidence shows that it is an important check against inadmissible evidence.

    Sir, let me assure this House that there are sufficient legal safeguards to firmly check any abuse in the police investigation. The law ensures that only properly obtained confession evidence is admitted as evidence of guilt. Under the Criminal Procedure Code and the Evidence Act, a confession which appears to have been obtained through any form of threat, inducement or promise is not admissible as evidence in court. The law places on the prosecution the burden of proving beyond reasonable doubt that the confession was made voluntarily. This is a heavy burden of proof.

    In addition, police carefully monitor all cases where confession evidence is ruled inadmissible. They will not hesitate to deal firmly with any officer who has run foul of proper practices and procedures or has resorted to assaults to obtain such evidence.

    Sir, having addressed the immediate concerns raised by Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon, let me caution that it is common for the defence to raise doubts on the credibility of the prosecution's case by casting aspersion on the manner in which such inculpatory evidence was obtained. Besides ruling inadmissible confession evidence which appears to have been obtained through any inducement, threat or promise made to the accused person, statements containing confession evidence will be ruled inadmissible if, for example, the court is satisfied that the requisite warning for caution which precedes the statement by an accused person has been inadequately explained or interpreted to him or if there were some other kind of irregularity in the recording of the confession or substantial non-compliance with any statutory requirements which will make it unsafe to admit it.

    Therefore, confession evidence can be rejected by the court for a variety of

Column: 1111

reasons. We cannot presume that every rejected confession implies an intentional abuse or malpractice by the investigator.

WATER RESOURCES IN SINGAPORE
(Enhancement)


    4. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what measures the Government has taken since 1990 in identifying and planning the enhancement of water resources in Singapore.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, I had explained to the House during the Committee of Supply debate in March this year the various efforts to develop new and alternative sources of water to meet our future needs. Perhaps the Member for Hougang was absent at that session.

    As I had pointed out to Members, if our water consumption continues to increase at 6% per annum, we will run short of water in six years' time, ie, in the year 2001. However, even if we succeed in halving the increase in water consumption to 3% per annum, we will only be able to delay this to the year 2011 when our 1961 Water Agreement with the Malaysians expires. This is why it is so crucial that we succeed in getting every Singaporean to use water carefully and to minimise water wastage.

    With regard to our local water resources, the Public Utilities Board's policy is to conserve and develop them to the maximum. The constraint here is land. Already, 50% of the land area of Singapore is used as water catchment areas. PUB has studied and implemented all feasible schemes to exploit local water sources. For instance, it has built storm water collection schemes in developed areas like Ang Mo Kio, Bedok, Tampines and Yishun. Rain water is also collected from the developed areas in Kranji, Pandan and the non-industrial areas in western Singapore.

    PUB has also considered creating additional reservoirs, for example, by damming up the sea between Pulau Ubin

Column: 1112

and the mainland. However, the problem is lack of a suitable catchment area to collect rainfall to fill the reservoir.

    To cut down on potable water requirements, there is an on-going effort by PUB to encourage the use of industrial water and sea water for non-potable purposes. Today, industries use about 7 million gallons of industrial water a day for cooling and washing. This represents about 3% of our daily potable water consumption. I have asked PUB to explore with the Ministry of the Environment the wider use of industrial water. Where feasible, we also encourage the use of sea water. Three of our power stations, three oil refineries and several other industrial and commercial organisations are already using sea water for cooling purposes.

    Besides conventional sources of water, PUB is also studying the feasibility of desalination. As I had explained in March, desalinated water will cost 7-8 times more than the current cost of treated water. When we will need to resort to using this expensive water will depend very much on how well Singaporeans control their water consumption. Nonetheless, we have to make the preparations now.

    Officers of the PUB, my Ministry and the Ministry of National Development will be visiting some countries that are already operating large-scale desalination plants to learn from their experience.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, when did the Government discover that the current water supply will not be able to meet the demand of Singapore's consumption?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the PUB constantly monitors the usage of water and that is why it has been able to implement various schemes that will come in place and be operational when the water consumption is needed. That is why we have also finalised and built the Linggiu Dam in Johor which enables us to supply the 250 million gallons of water a day that we are entitled to under our agreement with Malaysia. Similarly, we are now discussing with the Indonesians on the development of Bintan water resources as well as water resources on the mainland of Sumatra.

Column: 1113



     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, my question is: when did the PUB discover that the current water resources or whatever on-going efforts will not be able to meet the future demands of Singapore? When did the PUB discover that and thereby decided to impose the water conservation tax?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, this is not something which just appears from the blue. As I said, PUB monitors and projects water consumption all the time. That is why we have all these water schemes coming in place on a planned basis. However, under the agreement with Malaysia, we are entitled to only a certain amount of water. Based on our projection, with the first agreement expiring in the year 2011, if we can get Singaporeans to reduce the usage of water to 3% a year, we will be able to have enough water until the expiry of the first agreement.

    What we have to do now is to plan what will happen after that. As I have pointed out, one alternative is desalination and this is something which has been under study for a long time. We are now sending people to visit countries with operating systems so that we can have the desalination system in place when the water supply is needed. The realisation is not something that has just appeared. It is something that we have been tracking all the time and we feel that it is now timely for us to highlight to Singaporeans that we have to reduce to 3% a year in terms of our water consumption increase.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: The Minister said that PUB has been constantly tracking the consumption pattern and projecting the supply for Singapore. The Minister has also said that in the past the Government has taken various measures. What I would like to know is: since 1990, what are the detailed efforts and measures that have been specifically made before the PUB decided that there was no way out except to impose a water conservation tax?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the Member obviously does not quite understand what I have been telling him. The planning process is an on-going one. Why does he think that Singaporeans have never had

Column: 1114

the problem and trauma of having water shortage? It is because PUB has been monitoring and planning all the time.

    In terms of highlighting to Singaporeans the need to conserve water, that again is a message which comes out from the PUB regularly. In terms of ensuring that there is adequate supply, that again is something which PUB plans for. Why does he think all the new towns in the eastern part of Singapore have had the storm water collection systems in place. They were not put in place overnight. They were the result of many years of planning and many years of construction of the system. So it is not that we only started doing things in 1990. All the water development programmes have been on-going for many, many years already.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I am not saying that the Government is doing whatever planning for collecting more water now. What I am saying is that since the Government has imposed a water conservation tax as a measure, does it mean that the Ministry concerned has actually exhausted all the measures and efforts in trying to enhance the water resources in Singapore?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, as I have explained just now, all the feasible systems for collecting water in Singapore have already been explored and are already in place. Now we have to get Singaporeans to reduce water consumption. The campaign on the water conservation programme would be one way. However, as our past experience has shown, the price of water is also a very important factor, because that drives home the importance of water. In any case, once we go to desalinated water, which is inevitable, either in the year 2001 if we do not reduce our water consumption rate, or if we are able to halve it, in the year 2011, that will incur a tremendous increase in the price of water. So either way, the price of water will increase. It is better that we get Singaporeans to realise that water is precious and important and the water conservation tax in many ways drives home that importance today, rather than deferring it to the year 2011 or 2001.

Column: 1115



     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, the Minister says that the message of water conservation has been put across to the people of Singapore regularly. Other than the increase in the water conservation tax, can the Minister tell this House what other measures and campaigns the Government has embarked on to ask the people to conserve water since this matter was discussed in the Budget session?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, when this issue was brought up in the Budget debate, I had explained at that time to Members that the PUB would be embarking on a major water conservation campaign this year. This month long campaign will be launched on the last Saturday of June this year.

Column: 1115

CRITICISM OF GOVERNMENT POLICY ON INTERNET


    5. Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon asked the Minister for Information and the Arts whether the Government intends to take any action against persons who criticise Government policy on Internet and, if so, what action is contemplated.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Information and the Arts (Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M) (for the Minister for Information and the Arts): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government receives feedback, comments and suggestions on its policies via various channels such as this House, the media, the Feedback Unit, the Institute of Policy Studies and the Service Improvement Unit. The public is free to use Internet as another channel to give its views on Government policies. The Singapore InfoMap launched earlier this year makes this very convenient.

    Sir, as long as feedback, critical or otherwise, is constructive and no law of the land is broken, there is no reason for the Government to take action. Individuals should exercise responsibility when they participate in discussions on Internet just as in any other public forum. Those who engage in acts of defamation, libel, fraud or obscenity in Internet are of course liable to prosecution.

Column: 1116



    Internet is a new phenomenon. Some of our laws may not be adequate to deal with the legal problems in this new medium. This is a worldwide problem brought about by rapid advances in Information Technology. Internet will raise new and difficult legal issues in the areas of investigation, enforcement, evidence and prosecution. All over the world, new legal ground is being broken. For example, a Communications Decency Bill has been tabled in the US Senate to deal with pornography and obscene materials distributed through Internet, but it has not yet become law. Opponents argue that such a law will effectively kill Internet.

    Sir, we are undertaking a comprehensive review of these issues. The Government has established an inter-Ministry committee, involving MITA, the Singapore Broadcasting Authority, the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore, the National Computer Board, the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Attorney-General's Chambers, to study them and to recommend changes to our law. However, in crafting appropriate legislation, we must ensure that we do not stunt the growth of Internet and other applications of Information Technology in Singapore.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon (Nominated Member): Sir, will the Parliamentary Secretary please confirm therefore that people are free to express their views on Internet without fear of retribution, unless they break the law, of course?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M: Yes, Sir.

     Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Sir, does the Government intend to treat Internet like the press, specifically the written press?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M: Sir, as I have explained, this is a new medium. There is a committee now looking into various aspects of the new medium. We hope to come up with something to ensure that this new playground also ensures safety for those who are around and that they would not get hurt unnecessarily.

Column: 1117



     Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Sir, perhaps I can be more specific. Suppose that the Catherine Lim's article, which I believe appeared in the Sunday Times, actually appeared on Internet, would the Government actually reply like it did?

     Mr Speaker: Order. The question is out of order. It is hypothetical in nature.

DEFENCE INDUSTRY
(Percentage of R&D expenditure)


    6. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Finance how much of the national R&D expenditure (as a percentage of GDP) is channelled into the defence industry.

    Another consideration, an important one, is whether we would be setting a most undesirable precedent for future similar cases. Let me explain. Firstly, if we agree to appeals for stay of execution or clemency for foreign offenders, when there are no grounds to do so on the merits of the case, or on the evidence of the case, is it not surely an invitation, in every other case, for a foreign national and his lawyers to pressurise his home government to intervene on his behalf? What we do for one we will have to do for another. We value our relations with ASEAN colleagues highly. But there cannot be one standard for ASEAN appeals and another standard for non-ASEAN appeals. Also, it is not tenable for us to accede to appeals which have been highly publicised and turn down appeals which are of the same merit but were turned down because they have not become media issues and contentious issues.     Next, if we make special concessions for foreign nationals, for reasons other than on the merits of the case, Members should consider what happens to our own Singapore nationals who are also sentenced to death, ie, our nationals who also have no basis on merits, on evidence, to warrant clemency or stay of execution. Is the solution then to also give them a stay of execution when there are really no grounds on merits to do so? Surely, that cannot be done.     Mr Deputy Speaker, let me say a few words about the diplomatic phase. Our objective during this diplomatic phase was really to manage the events in a way that did not lead to further deterioration in relations with the Philippine government. And this phase was marked by the following features. First, exercise of restraint. Second, cooperating with President Ramos and his government. Third, keeping lines of communication open.

    First, exercise of restraint. Members have already spoken and noted that we had exercised as much restraint despite many provocative articles. They were so absurd and bizarre that no reasonable person would have given them much credence. But when reaction was called for, Members would agree that we gave a robust rebuttal.
